Kier has confirmed that FY19 trading remains in line, with the
Future Proofing Kier programme progressing well. H1 net debt
expected to be £130m (av ND £370m), with management
continuing to expect a FY19 net cash position (PHe £21m). No
change to the trading outlook with visibility enhanced by the
£10bn order book. We retain our earnings and average net debt
assumptions. Separately, Kier has announced that CEO Haydn
Mursell is stepping down with a search for an external successor
now underway. Shares trading on 5.6x Jun 20 and yield 7.3%
continue to offer material upside as investors appreciate the
strong market positions and growth opportunities. Buy

wayneJ (Morningstar pen on my desk - paint has flaked off and clip fallen off - about to head to the bin)

If you're like me, you'll have just said: "oh, 5.6x! Oh, Jun 20."

BE11:22am

Still, if you believe the balance sheet's strong enough now, it's pricing in a fair bit of Brexit.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Some would say it was only botched because too much column inches were given to shorters who promoted fear without regard to anyone other than themselves. Employees, hospitals, schools etc.. etc.. don't mean a thing to them.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Barclays:

BE11:22am

As expected results are set to be H2 weighted this year, reliant on cost savings under the FPK programme and this is flagged again in the statement with the £10m costs of implementing the programme in H1 (mostly headcount reductions) expected to be offset in H2.

Operationally recent trading has held up with sales rates in residential and property solid and contract wins in Infra and Buildings now giving the Group full visibility on revenues for the year within the order book (normal for this point in the year).

BE11:23am

And Canaccord.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian FT always likes a good shorter's Jackanory.
wayneJ @1st - isn't a similar excuse given by every company that has overleveraged; under-delivered on its forecasts etc
11:23 am
BE11:23am

The trading update contains no big surprises with the group on track to meet full year expectations and confirmation that it is trading well with some recent contract wins highlighted. Net debt at the end of December at c.£130m was only c.£110m better than the same time the previous year, but the group continues to expect a net cash position for the full year. Clearly, the balance sheet is now stronger which reduces potential pressure on the group from banks, suppliers and customers. It is also reassuring that the group remains on track in terms of trading and profit expectations. For now it looks as though it remains committed to FPK, which is understandable given it is targeting sensible efficiencies and improvements. Clearly, the appointment of the new CEO and the strategic changes they may choose to make will be important for the investment case. How working capital and average net debt develop over the next 12-18 months will also be closely monitored. Trading appears to be good currently but clearly macro risks remain for the wider sector. We maintain our HOLD rating.

wayneJ True story - one start up was raising money - I met management who had already burnt through several million - when I asked about the past cash burn I was told by the CEO that it had allowed her to 'grow as a person'

BE11:30am

We have had some concerns over Wood’s accounting for some time, and the magnitude of these concerns has increased post the AMFW acquisition (a company that we struggled with for some time on this front).

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Our concerns include:
– Including contingent consideration release in adjusted 2017 EBITA/EPS (this release arises because profits from an acquisition were lower than expectations).
– Arbitration: pro forma results for Wood/AMFW included a ~USD70m gain from an AMFW arbitration win. But H1 results included a ~USD10m exceptional loss for an arbitration lost by a Wood JV – even though the original contract arose from what was then a wholly-owned Wood operation.
– Some exceptional costs already recorded are not in provisions, but in current or other liabilities (such as near-term asbestos provisions, or onerous leases).
– We find it tricky to reconcile the company’s presentation of cash exceptionals (cUSD69m in H1) vs the amount implied in their accounts; we think this is because some payments are in working capital rather than separately provisioned currently.
– The post-acquisition upward adjustment of USD55m in provisions related to AMFW is also notable.
– Although we doubt there are any major challenges given the diversified nature of the portfolio, we also note that contract balances increased in H1, with advances from clients decreasing counter-cyclically but unbilled revenues increasing.

A. M. 'concerns over wood's accounting' sounds ominous.
FATDAZ @ref yes they showed some clips from that on the report I saw dreadful
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "A poorly financed / built hospital is a burden on society." What makes it poorly financed or poorly built? Kier had good business, 90% of 2019 sales were already booked and it had £10bn order book. There is nothing wrong with the company. Shorters played on the fear of the ignorant and it worked!
BE11:31am

– Software amortisation being included in adjusted earnings (although we adjust for this as standard across all of our coverage).

...... so the upshot here is that while Wood trades in line with the sector, the additional provisions/lease liabilities are equivalent to greater than 1.5x EBITDA

BE11:40am

The Company has been engaging with prospective lenders throughout the process and has revised certain aspects of our proposed US$3.0 billion stage 2 senior debt financing to modify the credit risk allocation amongst the various prospective lenders. The original structure contemplated two equal tranches of debt, one commercial bank tranche and one IPA guaranteed tranche, which would be drawn on a broadly pro-rata basis and also rank senior secure, pari passu. Our new structure contemplates three tranches of debt, totalling US$3 billion in aggregate, that will rank senior secure, pari passu, but will be drawn sequentially linked to key construction milestones. The first tranche will be an uncovered debt capital markets tranche, the second a commercial bank tranche, followed by the third being the IPA guaranteed bond tranche. This structure is designed to reduce both the risk and the quantum of any IPA guaranteed bond tranche to the taxpayer as by this time we will be past the major construction risks and POLY4 sales underway.

Given its strategic importance to investment and jobs for the "Northern Powerhouse" policy, it remains a priority focus for the Government to see the work done. Following Theresa May's defeat on her Brexit deal, it was the Sirius Minerals project that was one of the first questions to be asked at PMQs. The Treasury department that is working on the investment guarantee does not have a Brexit mandate and is not being distracted by the unstable political landscape. The collapse of two proposed nuclear plants, whose financing requirements are longer dated and more complex, only drives Government harder to deliver investment in the North

Whilst the new structure mitigates the projects’ reliance on the IPA / UK government guarantee, the addition of the uncovered bond adds another degree of complexity which could put at risk the prior timing for financial close by Q1’19. It also puts upward pressure on the interest cost, where prior guidance (unchanged in today’s release) is for an “all-in” cost of 6-7%. We reaffirm our view that the near-term equity thesis will be dictated by SXX’s ability to secure the next tranche of financing, and as such look for additional procurement contracts and off-take agreements as focal points going forward. We remain Overweight.

This compares to RPC trading on a current year PE of 8.9x and an EBITDA multiple of 6.3x.

BE11:55am

IG reported an H1 EPS decline of 15.9% to 24.6p, as expected given the impact of the ESMA regulations. The impact of the ESMA regulatory changes are now well embedded in the IG model and Q2 revenue declined 8% to £122.1m. Outside the ESMA impacted areas H1 revenue increased 13% to £85m and within the ESAM region revenue declined by 14% to £166m against the record H1 revenue performance achieved last year. Importantly IG continues to attract new clients with those generating £21.8m of revenue in H1 2019 against the £22.4m achieved in H1 2018. Furthermore, this was achieved with a lower marketing spend of £25.6m which declined by 7.6% on the first half of last year. While revenue from new clients was a little lower this does indicate that the ESMA intervention has not prevented IG from continuing to grow. The quality of the group's revenue and client base is also improving with 69% of group revenues now generated from professional investors and 51% of group revenues were generated from clients that have been with the group more than three years. We have made no material change to our forecasts and believe IG continues to offer good value with a very attractive 6.7% dividend yield.

BE11:57am

As the CFD industry matures and regulation is introduced to restrict the activities of the less scrupulous providers, we believe IG's market position should improve. We see this enhancing the quality of the group's income and believe its best in class practice will ensure that it is less negatively impacted from regulatory change. We expect the number of providers to shrink, as many of IG's smaller competitors are already struggling to break even. IG have guided that they expect the ESMA measures to reduce revenues by c.10% and we have already included this in our forecasts. We also see IG as broadening its financial services reach, having expanded with the creation of the Nadex exchange and its stockbroking services and the group is currently building a European MTF and a US FX trading business.

BE12:04pm

News: Dixons Carphone (DC) reported its Christmas trading statement (10 weeks to 5th Jan’19), with group LFL growth of +1% (company compiled consensus flat, GSe -0.6%) split UK&I electrical +2% (company compiled consensus +1%, GSe -1%), UK&I mobile down -7% (company compiled consensus -5%, GSe -4%), Nordics +3% (company compiled consensus +2%, GSe +2%) and Greece +19% (company compiled consensus +2%, GSe flat). Peak trading was in line with company expectations, with UK electricals market share increasing 30bps, driven by gaming (+60% yoy), Smart Tech, SDA and Vision.
UK Mobile was impacted by lower volumes of 24 month postpay (market decline of 8%) and growth in new longer than 24 months postpay segment. iD mobile displayed growth with the customer base reaching 975K and UK Credit improved strongly with customer base reaching 802K (711K in FY18).
Gross margins remain stable across the group.
Other KPIs: UK electricals online sales grew 8% yoy, representing 28% (+2ppt yoy) of total sales. International online sales grew 22%.
Guidance: Dixons Carphone has left the guidance unchanged (FY19 PBT of £300m)
What does it all means? Keeping all things equal, we expect company-compiled consensus FY19 PBT of £297m (-25% yoy) to remain stable.

wayneJ Re Dixons - one has to wonder exactly what creature CPW really was
BE12:05pm

Dixons Carphone is a very lowly priced share and has a strong relative market position in all its markets. DC has become a very leveraged play on the UK consumer, GBP exchange rate and Brexit developments, however it continues to take market share in its core electricals markets, although the markets themselves remain challenging. Its mobile offer faces a number of ongoing cyclical and structural headwinds and may be an ongoing drag on profitability, although DC should be able to release some value from its net receivable over me. Dixons Carphone trades on a CY19 P/E of 7x and
offers a dividend yield of c.5%.
